{{Infobox military conflict | conflict = Battle of Grand-Pré | partof = [[King George's War]] | image = | caption = | date = 19–20 August 1746 | place = [[North Adams, Massachusetts]] | result = French victory | combatant1 = {{flagcountry|Kingdom of France}}
Indians | combatant2 = {{flagcountry|Kingdom of Great Britain}} | commander1 = François-Pierre Rigaud de Vaudreuil | commander2 = Sergeant John HawksMichael D. Coe, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=1Mblbi4mymsC&pg=PA183 The Line of Forts]'' p.183 | strength1 = 1,000 | strength2 = 22 men, 3 women, 5 children | casualties1 = 1 killed, 16 wounded | casualties2 = 30 prisoners, 14 survived }} {{Campaignbox War Of Austrian Succession: King George's War}} The '''Siege of Fort Massachusetts''' (19-20 August 1746) was a successful siege of [[Fort Massachusetts (Massachusetts)|Fort Massachusetts]] (in present-day [[North Adams, Massachusetts]]) by a mixed force of more than 1,000 French and Indians from [[New France]]. The fort, garrisoned by a disease-weakened militia force from the [[Province of Massachusetts Bay]], surrendered after its supplies of ammunition and gunpowder were depleted. Thirty prisoners were taken and transported back to [[Quebec City|Quebec]], where about half of them died in captivity. ==References== {{reflist}} *Niles, Grace Graylock. [https://books.google.com/books?id=PhYzAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA137 ''The Hoosac Valley: its Legends and its History''] {{coord|42.7008|N|73.1092|W|source:wikidata|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fort Massachusetts, Siege of}} [[Category:Military history of New England]] [[Category:Military history of Canada]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1746]] [[Category:1746 in military history]] [[Category:Battles involving Great Britain]] [[Category:Sieges involving France]] [[Category:Battles of the War of the Austrian Succession]] [[Category:Pre-statehood history of Massachusetts|Siege of Fort Massachusetts]] [[Category:New France]] [[Category:1746 in North America]] {{UK-battle-stub}} {{France-battle-stub}}
